column6: Approach to stakeholder engagement
column7: RamsayÃ¢ÂÂs ongoing success and ability to grow is based on being a trusted partner for our doctors, patients and people. We identify our key stakeholders as groups we need to have regular and meaningful engagement with to ensure we are working towards shared outcomes. Engagement can be via formal or informal channels, and engagement processes may vary from region to region.

column6: Collective bargaining agreements
column7: s an employer, Ramsay commits to and respects workers' right to freedom of industrial association and employees to collectively bargain their terms and conditions of employment by applicable laws. Ã¢ÂÂ¢ This policy requires RamsayÃ¢ÂÂs regional operations to implement anti-discrimination and industrial relations practices and frameworks that support the commitment to negotiate in good faith with employees who collectively bargain employment terms and conditions in full compliance with the relevant jurisdiction's labour laws and industrial frameworks.

column6: Process to determine material topics
column7: RamsayÃ¢ÂÂs materiality assessment is informed by engaging our stakeholders to understand shared and emerging issues, our key business risks, and the Sustainability Accounting Standards Board's (now part of the IFRS Foundation's) Materiality Map for healthcare delivery. The problems are reviewed annually by our Global Sustainability Committee. This yearÃ¢ÂÂs review focused on ensuring the issues were consistent with feedback from more than 20 stakeholder interviews, including employees, doctors, government, funding partners, community groups and suppliers.

column6: List of material topics
column7: Clinical quality and excellence, robust and resilient business model, climate action and environment, people and culture, integrated quality asset and infrastructure, caring for communities, data and digital, good governance, responsible sourcing

column6: Management of material topics
column7: In sustainability terms, material issues are the most pressing issues affecting an organisation. Our material issues matter most to our stakeholders and impact our business drivers, competitive position and long-term value creation.
column24: https://www.ramsayhealth.com/en/sustainability/material-issues/

column6: Direct economic value generated and distributed
column7: The revenue contribution from businesses acquired in FY22, including Elysium and GHP, was $776.8m higher than the PCP. Net profit on the disposal of non-current assets reflects net profit on the sale of assets in Europe of $56.9m combined with profit on the sale of the Murray Valley hospital site in Australia of $3.4m. Income from the sale of development assets represents the sale of medical suites in Australia ($7.6m in profit included in nonrecurring items).

column6: Infrastructure investments and services supported
column7: Ramsay was founded in 1964 by Paul Ramsay AO (1936-2014) and has always focused on maintaining the highest standards of quality and safety, being an employer of choice and operating the business based on a culture known as The Ramsay Way and our purpose of 'people caring for people'. Ramsay was listed on the Australian Stock Exchange in 1997 and has a market capitalisation of A$12.3bn1 and an enterprise value (EV) of A$17.4bn1 (EV of A$23.4bn inclusive of lease liabilities). The Ramsay Group employs over 90,000 people globally.

column6: Significant indirect economic impacts
column7: Ramsay creates value by investing in and leveraging our value drivers to create a convenient, integrated, efficient and sustainable healthcare services platform delivering quality healthcare experiences and outcomes for patients, an attractive, industry-leading environment for our employees and clinicians and a supportive and effective service for our payors. At the centre of everything we do is our purpose of people caring for people.
